10.verse: A Filthy, Haughty Generation - Do not slander a servant to his master, or he will curse you, and you pay for it.

11.verse: There is a generation that curses its father and does not bless its mother.

12.verse: There is a generation that is pure in its own eyes, and yet is not cleansed from its filth.

13.verse: There is a generation whose eyes are so haughty, whose eyelids are lifted up disdainfully.

14.verse: There is a generation whose teeth are swords and whose molars are knives, to devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among humanity.

15.verse: The leech has two daughters: “Give! Give!” Three things are never satisfied, four never say, “Enough!”—

16.verse: Sheol, a barren womb, land that is not satisfied with water, and fire that never says, “Enough!”

17.verse: The eye that mocks a father and scorns obeying a mother— will be pecked out by ravens of the valley and eaten by young vultures!

18.verse: Three things are too amazing for me, four I do not understand:

19.verse: the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a serpent upon a rock, the way of a ship in the heart of the sea, and the way of a man with a maiden.

20.verse: Such is the way of an adulteress: she eats, wipes her mouth and says, “I have done nothing wrong.”

21.verse: Under three things the earth trembles, and under four it cannot bear up:

22.verse: under a slave when he becomes a king, a fool when he is stuffed with food,

23.verse: an unloved woman when she is married, and a handmaid when she displaces her mistress.

24.verse: Lessons from Creatures - Four things on earth are small, yet they are exceedingly wise:

25.verse: ants are creatures with little strength, yet they store up their food in summer;

26.verse: coneys are creatures with little power, yet they make their homes in the cliffs;

27.verse: locusts have no king, yet they advance together in ranks;

28.verse: a lizard you can catch with the hand, yet it is found in kings’ palaces.

29.verse: Three things are stately in their stride, four that move with stately bearing:

30.verse: a lion, mighty among beasts, who never backs down from anything;

31.verse: a strutting rooster, a male-goat, and a king with his army around him.

32.verse: If you have acted foolishly, exalting yourself, or if you have planned evil, put your hand over your mouth.

33.verse: For as churning milk produces butter, and twisting the nose produces blood, so stirring up anger produces strife.

1.verse: A Mother’s Warning - The words of King Lemuel, an oracle that his mother taught him:

2.verse: O my son, O son of my womb, O son of my vows,

3.verse: do not give your vigor to women, or your ways to what ruins kings.

4.verse: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, or for rulers to crave strong drink,

5.verse: lest they drink, forget what is decreed, and pervert justice for all the oppressed.

6.verse: Give strong drink to one who is dying, and wine to those who are bitterly distressed—

7.verse: let him drink, forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.

8.verse: Open your mouth on behalf of those unable to speak, for the justice of all who are destitute.

9.verse: Open your mouth, judge righteously, plead the cause of the poor and needy.

10.verse: A Woman of Valor - An accomplished woman who can find? Her value is far beyond rubies.

11.verse: Her husband’s heart trusts in her, and he lacks nothing valuable.

12.verse: She brings him good and not harm all the days of her life.

13.verse: She selects wool and flax and her hands work willingly.

14.verse: She is like merchant ships, bringing her sustenance from afar.

15.verse: She rises while it is still night and provides food for her household and portions for her servant girls.

16.verse: She considers a field and buys it. From the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.

17.verse: She girds herself with strength and invigorates her arms.

18.verse: She discerns that her business is good. Her lamp never goes out at night.

19.verse: She extends her hands to the spindle and her palm grasps the spinning wheel.

20.verse: She spreads out her palms to the poor, and extends her hands to the needy.

21.verse: She is not afraid of snow for her house, for her whole household is clothed in scarlet wool.

22.verse: She makes her own luxurious coverings. Her clothing is fine linen and purple.

23.verse: Her husband is respected at the city gates, when he sits among the elders of the land.

24.verse: She makes linen garments and sells them and supplies sashes to the merchants.

25.verse: Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs at the days to come.

26.verse: She opens her mouth with wisdom— a lesson of kindness is on her tongue.

27.verse: She watches over the affairs of her household, and does not eat the bread of idleness.

28.verse: Her children arise and bless her, her husband also praises her:

29.verse: “Many daughters have excelled, but you surpass them all.”

30.verse: Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain, but a woman who fears ADONAI will be praised.

31.verse: Give her the fruit of her hands. Let her deeds be her praise at the gates.
